text: she looks like an aspiring supermodel
but this young woman is something a
little more special Ariana Miyamoto is
the first mixed race woman ever to win
the title Miss Japan Ariana is what is
known here as a heart not foreign not
fully Japanese either I don't want to
think outside station I have lived in
Japan all my life but if I say I'm
Japanese people reply no you can't be
they don't believe it it sounds strange
but for us makes kids we need this word
- it gives us an identity while the
foreign media is flocking to meet her
the Japanese media has all but ignored
Ariana's victory to do that when you
were to cry and hold my dogs and you
must be like oh my daughter I'm
definitely getting more attention from
outside Japan when I walk down the
street here no Japanese people recognize
me lots of foreign tourists stop and say
congratulations
in fact the reaction of some Japanese on
social media has been downright hostile
is it okay to select a half ooh to
represent Japan tweeted one it makes me
uncomfortable to say she represents
Japan another this place still looks
incredibly homogeneous and Japan still
has a very narrow definition of what it
means to be Japanese it's built on a
myth the Japanese are special unique
even genetically separate from the rest
of us
of course it's not true Japanese are an
ethnic hotchpotch part korean part
Chinese hot Southeast Asian but the myth
is still strong and that makes being
different here very hard my code was
born in Japan to a Japanese mother and a
German father now she lives in Australia
I feel like I that Japan belongs to me
but I don't belong to it it's hard for
me to say I am Japanese because like I
said before I feel resistance from other
people if I say that you know they'll
say no you're not you're you're half I
feel like I just accepted my place in
this society as what I am and who I am
so it only hurts when I tried to be
Japanese the people like Michael and
Ariana are part of a growing trend one
in 50 children born in Japan today is
biracial twenty thousand babies a year
